Yes and no.

Yes, for reasons Mike wrote. No, for reasons I am about to write.

Your CLASSPATH had a glaring error. I'm not sure Mike saw it. Correct me if 
you did, Mike.

You were putting the properties file in the CLASSPATH, and not the folder at 
the root of the properties file. To be precise, you were putting 
"..../junit/runner/excluded.properties" in your CLASSPATH instead of just 
the folder containing "junit/runner/...". I think Mike actually mentioned 
it, but I'm not sure you did it.

JUnit looks for a properties file at junit.runner.excluded.properties, 
meaning that Java looks in your CLASSPATH and tries to match 
X/junit/runner/excluded.properties for each X in the CLASSPATH. If you have 
Y/junit/runner/excluded.properties in the CLASSPATH, Java will try to load 
Y/junit/runner/excluded/properties/junit/runner/excluded.properties, which 
it will surely not find.

I hope this is clearer.

JBR.

==================
Thanks.
That explains.

--- In junit@y..., Mike Clark <mike@c...> wrote:
>yours_jeeva wrote:
>
> > Mike,
> > It works now. Works with fork on.
> > Works even if i remove the excluded.propoerties!
> > Does that make sense?
> >
>
>Yes - it does make sense.  Here's why...
>
>Without forking a new JVM, the test runs in the same environment as
the Ant executable
>itself.  And, if you use the Ant task example I posted, then the
reloading classloader
>isn't employed.
>
>Mike
